docs.lead_paragraph: Xavier University, a Jesuit university in Cincinnati, said this week it would end birth-control coverage for its employees in July, a move that has divided faculty members and students.

docs.lead_paragraph: Optimistic about a possible Supreme Court ruling against the law, lawmakers are giving past proposals a second look, with lowering health costs a priority.

headline.seo: Republicans Examine Alternatives to Obama Health Plan
headline.main: Looking Ahead, Republicans Examine Options in Health Care Fight
headline.print_headline: Looking Ahead, Republicans Examine Options in Health Care Fight

docs.abstract: Republican lawmakers are beginning to devise alternatives to Pres Obama's health care law so they can be ready if the Supreme Court strikes down any significant parts of it; they remain optimistic about the possibility of a court victory, and are giving past proposals a second look, with lowering health costs a priority.
docs.snippet: Optimistic about a possible Supreme Court ruling against the law, lawmakers are giving past proposals a second look, with lowering health costs a priority.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama said the Republican budget would deepen inequality in the United States, part of an indictment of the party that included his likely opponent in the fall, Mitt Romney.

headline.main: Obama, in Talk, Calls House G.O.P. Budget the Work of Rightist Radicals
headline.print_headline: Obama, in Talk, Calls House G.O.P. Budget the Work of Rightist Radicals

docs.abstract: President Obama condemns federal budget adopted by House Republicans, saying it would greatly deepen inequality in the United States; paints it as the manifesto of a party that has swung radically to the right; attack is part of an indictment of the GOP that includes Mitt Romney, his likely opponent in the fall.
docs.snippet: President Obama said the Republican budget would deepen inequality in the United States, part of an indictment of the party that included his likely opponent in the fall, Mitt Romney.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move likely to alter treatment standards in hospitals and doctors' offices nationwide, a group of nine medical specialty boards plans to recommend on Wednesday that doctors perform 45 common tests and procedures less often, and to urge patients to question these services if they are offered. Eight other specialty boards are preparing to follow suit with additional lists of procedures their members should perform far less often. The recommendations represent an unusually frank acknowledgment by physicians that many profitable tests and procedures are performed unnecessarily and may harm patients. By some estimates, unnecessary treatment constitutes one-third of medical spending in the United States.

headline.main: Doctor Panels Recommend Fewer Tests For Patients

docs.abstract: Medical specialty boards plan to recommend that doctors perform 45 common tests and procedures less often, and to urge patients to question these services if they are offered; recommendations represent frank acknowledgment by doctors that many profitable treatments are performed unnecessarily but change of heart also reflects changes in the health care marketplace. docs.lead_paragraph: The study used government data to rank each American county by health indicators like obesity and premature death, and considered factors like the presence of fast-food restaurants.

headline.main: Longevity Up in U.S., but Education Creates Disparity, Study Says
headline.print_headline: Longevity Up in U.S., but Education Creates Disparity, Study Says

docs.abstract: Study conducted by researchers at the University of Wisconsin finds that Americans are living longer, but the gains in life span are accruing disproportionately among those with a college education.
docs.snippet: The study used government data to rank each American county by health indicators like obesity and premature death, and considered factors like the presence of fast-food restaurants.
